prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: When Disclosure Is a Breach of Confidence—Partly public and partly private information

para.paratext: Where the information is partly public and partly confidential, the recipient is only allowed to make use of the public portion of it. The leading English Court of Appeal case of Seager v. Copydex Ltd.[1] makes this clear:

The law on this subject does not depend on any implied contract. It depends on the broad principle of equity that he who has received information in confidence shall not take unfair advantage of it. He must not make use of it to the prejudice of him who gave it without obtaining his consent. The principle is clear enough when the whole of the information is private. The difficulty arises when the information is in part public and in part private. As, for instance, in this case … When the information is mixed, being partly public and partly private, then the recipient must take special care to use only the material which is in the public domain. He should go to the public source and get it: or, at any rate, not be in a better position than if he had gone to the public source. He should not get a start over others by using the information which he received in confidence. At any rate, he should not get a start without paying for it.

Putting aside other intellectual property arguments, it is clear that where a party uses publicly available information, even to manufacture a product that imitates the product of another manufacturer, there will be no misuse of confidential information. In Eldon Industries Inc. v. Reliable Toy Co.,[2] the Ontario Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal of a failed action for damages for breach of confidence. The court relied on the reasons of the trial judge, as follows:

I do not think the truck was delivered by Mr. Stevens to Mr. Kalef in such a way that it could be said that Mr. Kalef stood in a confidential relationship to Mr. Stevens with respect to the design of the truck. The truck was advertised in a catalogue; it was on the market. Some had been sold in Canada, and it was generally on the market in the United States. There was nothing confidential about the design of the truck. It was not as if Mr. Stevens had drawings of a proposed truck that he intended to put on the market and he showed these to Mr. Kalef for the purpose of Mr. Kalef's showing them to a customer of his and Mr. Kalef then turned them over to the Reliable company, and the Reliable company used the drawings to create a truck.

I agree with the learned Chief Justice that Eldon having furnished National not with a design but with a completed article manufactured according to that design, the article did not constitute confidential material from which a confidential relationship could arise between those parties. As was pointed out, that truck had been extensively advertised and pictorially exhibited in a catalogue, was readily available in the United States market, and 500 models had been sold in Canada. We are not dealing with the question which would arise if the appellants had supplied National with the plans or drawings of a truck which they proposed to manufacture and market to enable National to show them to a customer, and which National then converted to its own use by delivering them to its co-defendant for the purpose of manufacture from the said drawings.[3]
The court implied that it might have reached a different decision if the defendants had relied upon any drawings produced by the plaintiffs.[4]

In the leading Canadian case, LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[5] the Supreme Court of Canada relied on a number of facts, based upon the evidentiary conclusions reached by the trial court, in holding that the defendant was not entitled to make use of certain information that had been provided in confidence. LAC Minerals had the advantage of various discussions with Corona's geologist who interpreted his original findings and explained his theory to LAC. The geologist also allowed LAC's representatives to examine various drill cores and individual assays. Thus, the information obtained from Corona by LAC clearly “went beyond what had been imparted publicly” in a newsletter and a public investor's meeting. Much of the information provided by Corona to LAC “was private and had not been published”. In summary, LAC Minerals had been provided with more information than the general public and was not allowed to use the private portion of that information for its own benefit. As was the case in LAC, where any confidential information has been used, the onus of distinguishing public versus private portions of information should be on the party claiming no improper use.

At least one Ontario judge has held that it is inappropriate for a court to enjoin specific information it cannot identify within the context of the whole, even where there is a finding that the sum of the information is unique.[6]
